Entry.3: Preparation for landing Dardanelles – forming barrel Piers etc.
Entry.5: Nothing interest – Piers – All going well.
Entry.7: Did a little barrel Piering. Things quiet.
Entry.9: Still doing a little work. Nothing of interest.
Entry.12: Transferred to "Malda". Got Webb equipment. Heard that a Torpedo boat "Turkish" attempted to torpedo a transport coming in a few nights ago but missed & was in turn beached. Panic on transport resulted in a good many being drowned
Entry.13: Nothing of much consequence today. Was told that we are to form part of first landing party.
Entry.14: Went ashore tonight to practice landing together with the Infantry who are to form attacking party. Informed that our work is to be demolishing guns.
Entry.15: Wet and windy. Nothing of interest doing.
Entry.16:
Still waiting orders to proceed Dardanelles

24

Left "Malda" 11 am. Destroyer & went aboard "Queen". Two Coys 9th Batt & 2.3.
Entry.17: F. Coy Engs. Left Mudros Harbor about 2 P.M. together with large number war craft including "Queen Elizabeth" & a great many transports. Expect to land Dardanelles to make night attack "Gaba Tepe" 3 a.m. tomorrow
Entry.18: Left Queen about 1.30 am with Destroyer towing. Landed 4.30 amid a perfect Hell of lead fired when we were about 100 yds away & we charged through until we were only 10 yds away from Enemy. Infantry charged magnificently & drove the Turks back over 1 mile before midday. Shrapnel on landing & heavy firing continued all day but the operations were carried out splendidly. The Turks position should have been almost impregnable. Our Infantry work was wonderful & drove everything before it. Our casualties for day said to be about 2 Bttlns. Our Coy lost 4 killed and about 4 wounded.
Entry.19: Our Forces continue to have good success. Losses not so heavy as expected. The bombardments of the Enemy’s position by our boats was enormous & tremendous amount of firing being done & keeping the Enemy’s reinforcements back British troops coming up behind Enemy.
Entry.20:
Hard fighting all day. Our boys have pressed but holding their own navy do splendid work. Queen Elizabeth reported to have blown up Fort at Shanuk. Tonight No. 1 Sec.Engs trenching and barbed wire. 

 up near firing line centre. Q. Lizzy reported to have blown up "Goeben" Australian Submarine passed Narrows
Entry.21: Continued fighting with advantage for our boys. Enemy’s shrapnel not so troublesome. Navy doing good work. No. Sec. left for Base about 8 a.m. & left again 6 p.m. to form a new firing line trenches. A lot of hard work and having little sleep.
Entry.22: Fighting still going on. Nothing fresh – holding our own. Engineers doing improvements to trenches. Cpl. Turnley. Sap. Banks & I were in Left Centre firing line tonight building an observation post
Entry.23: Things going well. Engineers working improving trenches & roads.
Entry.24:
5-15

Things progressing favorably for us. Turks made a big show on centre but were easily repulsed Cpl. Turnley Sap Banks & I were in Centre firing line tonight to place

1st 

machine gun but owing to Turks heavy fire & hand grenades were unable to do anything
Entry.25: Still working hard on improvements in field. Worked most of night on communication trenches. Sap Howlett was killed by shrapnel having half his head blown off while the nose cap from same shell almost blew the knee cap from Sap Drane. Our heavy Artillery fire on centre on enemy’s line caused great loss.
Entry.26: Battle still progressing favorably for us. Engineers still working improvements. I was coved by fall earth about 11 P.M. damage slight.
Entry.27: Expect forward movement soon. Engineers Casualties to date about twelve. Very hard work now. No luxuries.
Entry.28: Exempt duty owing to injuries to shoulder last night. Sapping & improvements going on as usual. Things favorable.
Entry.29: Things going just the same. Marking time. Some reinforcements came today.
Entry.30:
5.15

Heavy shrapnel from Enemy today not much damage. Our guns said to be doing much damage to Enemy’s trenches. Still on sick list. Things favorable. The spot where land took place to be called "Anzac", the name being formed from first letters from N. Zealand and Australian army Corps. Other landings further south being "Doughty Wilie" and Lancashire landings.
Entry.31: Our Artillery had the better of the duel today causing the enemy to evacuate some of their trenches. Heavy Enemy shrapnel on the Beach
Entry.32:
Still holding position firmly. Heavy shrapnel fire by Enemy.

10th 

Things just as usual. Enemy’s shrapnel not so heavy as usual. Some of Battalion made attack on Enemys position but without success & sustained heavy loss.
Entry.33:
Very heavy bombardment going on down our coast by other war boats. Read out in Orders. Portion 2nd Battalion highly commended for great and gallant bravery for rescuing marines 
from isolated trench
Entry.34: inst. from a very dangerous position they had got into in enemy’s lines. News of the sinking of the Lusitania by German submarine. Large number lives lost.
Entry.35: Still on light duty – am Acting Storeman. Our artillery fairly active today. During the afternoon up to 8 P.M. there has been terrific bombardment down the coast by our war boats there being one continuous war. Lft Dawkins struck by shrapnel today do not know if fatal.
Entry.36: Nothing noteworthy today. Work going on as usual. Lft Dawkins killed with shrapnel yesterday (2nd F. Coy). War craft bombardment not so fierce today. Enemy’s shrapnel quiet.
Entry.37: Things quiet. Firm hold on position. Not much Artillery fire. Enemy shrapnel fire quiet. Still on light duty & acting storeman.
Entry.38: Nothing fresh happened today still firmly holding position. Not much Artillery fire.
Entry.39: A fair amount of shrapnel flying about today from both side. Our guns said to be doing good work. Armorer Sgt Taylor Killed by shrapnel while in his dugout today. Also Cpt Napier wounded by bullet in leg necessitating amputation (3rd F Coy)
Entry.40: Nothing startling today. Things going satisfactorily.
Entry.41: Heavy Artillery duels. Enemy using 8.2" Guns but doing little damage.
Entry.42: Enemy opened early with an attack on our Front & heavy shrapnel fire. Also did some damage to our trenches with 4.7" during the day. I was revetting trenches & placing travases with party Infantry. During the afternoon the shelling by the Enemy with 4.7" of our trenches was heavy. The part where I was working having 6 shells within 60’ doing a good deal of damage blowing an overhead cover I was engaged on. I was about 10’ away at the time & we had to abandon the work for the time being. During the attack in the early hours of the morning it is estimated that the Enemy had about 1500 killed while our losses were about 12 per Battalion.
Entry.43: Things were quiet today. The Turk apparently having had enough of it yesterday.
Entry.44: Fairly heavy Artillery fire today by enemy using some heavy guns but not much damage done.
Entry.45: went to Beach today to replace some piers that have been damaged by heavy weather. Worked half day and got Pier in working order.
Entry.46:
Worked all day on Piers. Nothing startling happened. 

24th

Worked all day 
Piers
 finished Piers!
Entry.47: An Armistice was arranged today for the purpose of burying the dead & lasted from 7 a.m. to 4 p.m. Fighting proceeding steadily.
Entry.48: Triumph torpedoed today by Enemy’s Submarine about 12.30 p.m. & sunk in about ½ hour. Number lives lost so far unknown. This is a heavy loss to us as she was doing splendid work on land Batteries & has fired more rounds during war than any other boat in Navy. Sub. still at large. Other things quiet.
Entry.49: Making wire entanglements today. Things quiet.
Entry.50: "Majestic" sunk by Enemy Sub off "Helles Point" this morning. She was old but serviceable boat. Other things quiet. Started to tunnel toward enemy to form new fine trenches.
Entry.51: Superintending work in sap going toward Enemys trench. Things quiet. Rumoured "Baccante" sunk by Enemy sub. Not confirmed.
Entry.52: Early this morning there was heavy Artillery fire all along line - the enemy opening with heavy Artillery fire continuing till about 6 a.m. On our Left Enemy attacked but were cut up after severe fighting with very heavy losses. The 13th & N. Zealanders eventually taking two trenches. Our casualties are put down at about 200 while it is estimated that the Turks lost about 1500.
Entry.53: Enemy attempted feeble attack on Left Centre about 1 a.m. but were subjected to very heavy fire from our Artillery & were easily repulsed. Our boys counter attacking & taking a couple of trenches with light losses while the Turks losses must have been very heavy. Principle value of trenches gained was the fact that one was used by Snipers.
Entry.54: Things quiet today. Captured trench used by Enemy for purpose mining toward our lines.
Entry.55:
6.1915

Nothing importance today still holding enemy well in hand.
Entry.56: I am still looking after work in tunnels driving toward enemys lines. Enemy keeping quiet. Not much of interest doing.
Entry.57: Things quiet today. Tonight our boys made a demonstration firing & cheering in the hope of inducing the enemy to open fire but without effect. Enemy sapping toward our trenches. Our tunnels going well. Reported one of our boat in Gulf Xeros firing across land completely destroyed large supply Enemys stores.
Entry.58: Things as usual during the day. Tonight a party of Engineers proceeded to 1st Battln lines to go out & attempt to demolish Enemy’s M. Gun. They were preceded by party bomb throwers but unfortunately this party surprised party Turks in hidden Trench & at once heavy fire was opened on our boys & they had to give up the attempt.
Entry.59: Heavy firing continued during the morning following last nights affair & our boys attacked driving the Turks from a trench which had to be abandoned later owing to enfilade fire from M. Guns. Some prisoners were taken & fair amount loss inflicted on Enemy. Our losses about 8 killed & 20 wounded . Very heavy. Enemy shrapnel during morning.
Entry.60: Things quiet today. A little shrapnel from Turks. Went to church service in evening.
Entry.61: Nothing fresh to report. Little shrapnel fire from Enemy, desultory rifle fire both sides.
Entry.62: Fair amount Artillery fire from our Batteries usual exchange of rifle fire.
Entry.63: Still driving on toward Enemy’s lines. Enemy forming new firing line 30 yds nearer our position. Things as usual.
Entry.64: Nothing fresh to report, usual rifle fire.
Entry.65: Making good progress towards Enemy trenches with our tunnels. During early morning opened on Enemy’s lines with bombs from Japanese mortar followed by Star Rockets & heavy rifle fire. Enemy replied with rifle. Results unknown. During afternoon enemy opened with heavy shrapnel fire but did not do much damage.
Entry.66: Enemy active again with shrapnel a few men being killed by it. Otherwise things going as usual steady fire all along the line.
Entry.67:
Heavy burst shrapnel fire today not much damage done attended unique church parade this afternoon. The subject taken for sermon was from the life of St Paul dealing with his travels to Macedonia in answer to the "Cry from Macedonia". Seated on the hill side on a road leading up to the communication trench of 3rd immediately in front of us was the Historic Island of Samothracia close by whose shores St Paul passed on his way to Macedonia the land itself being right in front (not too sure of this) but too far away to see. A little to the left Imbros Island. As we looked across the water we look at one of the most gorgeous & most beautiful sunsets I have ever witnessed the sky being partly covered by fleecy clouds & these were lit up by most beautiful & brilliant light effects in red & gold & silver while under the shadow of the Island itself the sea was marked off in beautiful shades & strips of pearly light. As the night advanced the sun set in golden glory the sky effects becoming deeper & darker red while the Islands became darker & the beautiful purple pink appeared. Then night and the stars & the "Great Bear" which we have 

been accustomed to look at in the North as we used to look at the dear old Cross in the South. While this was happening a Field Gun was hurling shells close over our head into the Turkish lines in amongst the very people who have done so much against Christianity which St. Paul did so much to establish.
Entry.68: A fairly quiet day although there was a fair amount of Artillery fire from both sides.
Entry.69: Rather heavy Artillery duel between our guns & Turks at "Cape Helles" a tremendous bombardment by our boats is going on. From 8 p.m. to midnight could be heard a continuous rattle of rifle & machine gun fire. Rumoured that our Forces down south making good progress.
Entry.70: Rumoured today that the British & French at Cape Helles made good progress yesterday. No official confirmation. Things quiet here.
Entry.71: Nothing fresh to write. Battle still progressing as usual.
Entry.72: Light Artillery & rifle fire on both sides nothing fresh.
Entry.74: Nothing fresh. Same energetic work going on, sapping & driving toward Enemies lines.
Entry.75: Little artillery & rifle fire during day. About 10.30 p.m. we opened with heavy rifle fire & bombs all along the line to which the Turks vigorously replied. Our fire had been to find out their relative strength at different points along the firing line and it worked well.
Entry.76: Principle work being done driving tunnels in front firing line to form new fire trench. When this is complete we should have a very strong position, much stronger than we have at present. Other things as usual.
Entry.77: Same performance as usual, sapping. Artillery and rifle fire. Nothing fresh.
Entry.78: Everything going well. Usual exchange Artly rifle fire.
Entry.79: Usual work in tunnels & Fire trench & same old exchange of lead.
Entry.80: Work in new firing line going well as is everything with us. Nothing fresh – usual exchange shells & bullets.
Entry.81: Nothing out of the ordinary today. Attended Church Service about 7.30 p.m. A goodly crowd gathers to these Services on the hillside & all appear to look forward to having them. As at last service that I attend here there was a beautiful sunset & instead of the loud gun that was firing on that occasion there was a Destroyer firing in the same position work still going on in new trenches.
Entry.82: There was tremendous bombardment of Enemys position by our boats & land Guns near Cape Helles today. Along the hillside the smoke from bursting Naval shells resembled a bushfire. In the afternoon we made an attack on some Turk trenches in front of our Right Flank & some of the Light horse with part 11th Battln advanced about 800 yds & found a great many dead in some of the trenches that the Turks had abandoned about 8.30 p.m. we opened fire along the line again & under cover of this fire our boys abandoned the trenches captured earlier in the afternoon & returned again to our lines. Our casualties were about 250. During the night some troops were landed down the coast also British French & Indian advanced about 1,000 yds near Krithia & firmly hold position gained.
Entry.83:
More heavy bombardment down coast result unknown. About dusk there was a violent dust storm here & immediately both our boys & Turks opened with very 

heavy rifle fire & about midnight the Turks attacked on our left after our boys had made a light attack to draw a counter which proved quite successful. It is estimated that fully 400 Turks were killed 250 being taken from our own lines next morning where we had allowed them to penetrate. Our losses were light, reported to be about 50.
Entry.84: Things were quiet today & scarcely any fire could be heard down C. Helles way. In afternoon I took a walk down toward Gaba Tepe to have a look at lines there.
Entry.85: Today again could be heard very heavy Artillery fire down C. Helles way & it is reported that the British & French are doing very well there. Quiet here.
Entry.86: Nothing fresh. Doing good work strengthening position.
Entry.87: Light Artillery fire from both sides. Nothing much doing working in tunnels.
Entry.88: Fairly heavy shrapnel from Enemy. About 10 p.m. we exploded mine & destroyed Enemy’s tunnel near German Officers Trench. Said to have done good work!
Entry.89: Enemy firing 11.2" shells today which appear to be fired from a gun which has been brought up close to lines. They also open early in morning with heavy shrapnel fire. Damage slight. Big gun silent this afternoon.
Entry.90: A fairly large amount of Artillery fire from both sides about 6 p.m. Enemy commenced firing 6" shell. One of these shells passed so close to my head that I could feel the warmth from it & lodged right alongside the officers cook house, tearing a huge hole in the ground but doing no more damage than blowing things about a bit. Other things going as usual.
Entry.91: This evening the enemy fired some more 11.2" shells blowing some of our trenches about badly & burying a good many but as far as I know no one killed.
Entry.92: There was some heavy Artillery firing today chiefly from our guns & the Monitor. During the afternoon a rather amusing incident occured although it may easily have serious consequences. In one of our tunnels that had been mined by us or rather in the Crater made by the explosion a few Turks had installed themselves. Our Infantry Guard was called out while our boys tried to drop a couple of Japanese bombs in but on re-entering found that the Turks had taken up the position that we had firmly held & thus were masters of the position.
Entry.93: During the day a good deal of Artillery fire has been exchanged. During the afternoon the Enemy sent over some 6" shells knocking the trenches about a good deal & wounding more or less seriously some of our boys. Today we put a mine into the tunnel we lost to the Turks yesterday but again the Turk rushed across the open ground & occupied the Crater. While in this crater the Turks are safe from our fire while they command the tunnel whence as if our boys were to occupy it they would come directly under the Enemy’s fire. About 6.30 p.m. Cpl Gough was shot through the head just above our camp & died almost instantly.
Entry.94: Today has not been very eventful. A good deal of Artillery fire has been exchanged but nothing else worth noting.
Entry.95:
This afternoon there has been some heavy Artillery work & one of our Cruisers has been 

close inshore firing somewhere across the Peninsular repeatedly sending broadsides across. From six to seven PM the Enemy sent along a lot of shrapnel & some heavy shells causing some casualties but although some heavy shells burst in our camp (Engs) covering us with debris we had no casualties. Tonight we opened fire all along the line to divert the Turks attention from Achi Baba where an attack is to be made.
Entry.96: About 8 a.m. our Guns opened with heavy fire on the Enemy’s position & we also opened up heavy rifle fire all along our line again to keep the Enemy from turning his attention to Achi Baba. Shortly after the Enemy subjected us to very heavy artillery fire destroying part of our trenches & causing a good many casualties. One large shell burst amongst our H Quarters wounded 3 of our boys & killing an Infantry man & seriously wounding another. A little earlier Sap. McMahon had his arm broken by a piece of falling earth while Sap. Wells was killed in a Sap. by a bomb.
Entry.97: More Artillery duels today the enemy subjecting us to a heavy bombardment again in the afternoon doing considerable damage to our trenches & causing some casualties.
Entry.98: The Turks again favored us with heavy shelling this morning blowing some of our trenches & causing some casualties although there was not much damaged done. Our Artillery appears to be doing better work than formerly. Repairing trenches today.
Entry.99: Relieving Cpl Lundy in charge tunnels D.1.A, D.3. D.3A. He has gone for a rest & I take his place until his return.
Entry.100:
Work going on well in tunnels. Heavy bombardment this afternoon causing a good many

casualties & damage to our trenches. Just below our camp there is a notice board & while Sap Lalor was reading some orders on it a shell land a few ft from him lifting him about 20 ft & landing him through a blanket roof on a Q.M’s Store onto the floor some 8’ below. He was rather badly wounded but it is thought that he will get over it alright.
Entry.101: Fairly heavy bombardment this afternoon more casualties & damage to our trenches. Our Artillery is doing good work.
Entry.102: As usual on the Sabbath as much work as usual. Nothing of interest.
Entry.103: A good deal of shelling from Enemy doing some damage to our trenches causing some casualties. Our Artillery replied I believe with good effect.
Entry.104: Fairly heavy shelling from Enemy early in morning & again in the afternoon. Our Artillery was fairly active too & appeared to be getting well into the enemy’s trenches. Usual exchange of rifle fire and bombs.
Entry.105: Nothing fresh today except that our Artillery put in more than usual.
Entry.106: It is thought highly probable that the enemy will make an attack tonight & every precaution is being taken to give them a warm reception. Our Howitzers gave them a particularly warm time today.
Entry.107: The expected attack did not eventuate last night. Every preparation had been made to give them a warm reception but beyond that a good deal of firing about 1.30 a.m. nothing occurred but Artillery is busy again today & the enemy has put in a good deal too this afternoon & also fired some very heavy bombs. One shell 75mm fell amongst our dugouts but luckily did no damage as it did not explode.
Entry.108:
Artillery has been busy again today & this afternoon & this afternoon the enemy subjected us to very heavy shell fire. They also fire some heavy bombs about 12" from a trench mortar but did not do much damage. One of these bombs landed right amongst our stores & burst with great force. It fell right amongst some of our men but did not explode immediately on falling, allowing them to get away without damage. A little before this a large piece from one of there bombs which burst a good way away came straight for my happy home but got tangled in a shirt hanging on a bush outside & then came and knocked a hole through the roof about 1’ long but did no further damage I’m very thankful to say as I wasn’t home at the time.

24th

A small bomb also lobbed in a dugout & wounded Cpl Wood in the leg. He was taken to the Hospital.
Entry.109: Every preparation has been made to meet an attack from the Enemy as it is thought certain that will attack before long as there has been large forces of Reinforcements brought up. More heavy shelling on both side & a good deal of bombarding throughout the night.
Entry.110:
No attack from the enemy though they appear to be very nervy. We shelled them heavily during the night with howitzer & from Destroyer & again today. During the day we successfully exploded a mine under an old mine crater that they had occupied & were working in. Late in the Evening they again bombarded us with high explosive & other shells blowing our trenches about rather badly in places but did not cause many casualties. 

Cpt Hartland was covered with earth & died from the effects. Many bombs were exchanged during the afternoon. n mjmnmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmn mmmmmmmmmmmnmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmm
Entry.111: Still the attack does not come. The enemy is firing a good many shells & bombs a scattered area evidently hoping to cause a demoralising effect but not doing much damage. Work Sap, etc. going as usual.
Entry.112: Work going on well in tunnels toward Enemys lines. Fairly heavy Artillery fire no great damage done to our trenches.
Entry.113: Nothing fresh doing today. Usual exchange bombs, shells, bullets & other missiles.
Entry.115: About 9 p.m. heavy fire broke out all along our line & our boys made & attack on the right. 11th Battln attacking. They succeeded in capturing about 200 yds enemy’s trenches & holding them about 50 yds in advance of our lines. Three mines were exploded by 2nd F. Coy before attack & four failed to explode. Casualties on our side about 10 killed & 30 wounded. We shelled enemy position all night a monitor & a Destroyer taking part & doing good work. Officers in Charge where attack was made say that Enemy’s Artillery fire on our position was magnificent.
Entry.116: Not much shelling today our guns doing most of what was done. Early in the morning a German "Taube" flew over & dropped 3 bombs but without much effect but one of 1st F Coy was wounded in the arm (Sap Hartridge)
Entry.117:
11th Battln still holding position taken from Enemy. Not much doing today except that enemy dropped a great many large bombs during the afternoon & a good many large shells from a direction not used

by them for a long time. Our Artillery lively as usual. A Taube flew over but sooner "Imsbid" after dropping a couple of bombs some where near our Trench evidently afraid of being hit by numbers of M Guns fired at him.
Entry.118: Not much doing today. Roughly same as yesterday.
Entry.119: Several thousand "Tommies" arrived last night evidently to take part in the attack to be carried out very soon. There are now active preparations for an attack in the near future. About 6 a.m. a Taube flew over the "Tommies" dropped a couple of bombs but without results. Heavy bombardment by our Howitzer & lively reply by Enemy. Alls well
Entry.120: More Tommies arrived last night & more 6th Re Inforcements. Expect big bombardment by our Guns tonight.
Entry.121: Today has been a very eventful one. Early in the forenoon 9 howitzers & 18 pounders began a heavy bombardment which became more intense as the day advanced while in the afternoon 2 Monitors & a couple of Cruisers took a hand. At times the bombardment of the Turkish lines was terrific our Howitzer shell doing great work. About 3 p.m. 4th Battl charged & took the "Lone Pine" & held it. Bombardment has continued right into the night. The Turks did not reply so vigorously as excepted altho’ they put a lot of shell in & there fire becoming more effective after dark. Our casualties not very heavy.
Entry.122:
The battle still rages & is developing satisfactorily. During the night the bombardment continued (last night) without a break. A party attempted to go out to the Snipers trench with the intention of filling it in but for some reason or other they did not get there and 

the movement was a failure. About midnight we blew two mines under the "German Officers Trench" & the 6th Battln made an attempt to charge it but were met with terrific fire & partly through some bungling here again the movement was not a success, a good many being lost for nothing. The least that can be said of the 6th Battln who were mostly Re Inforcements is that they were certainly not a success. At the "Salt Lake" on our left a huge Force of Tommies were land & they are making a good advance on the Turks "Right Flank". On our "Left" the N. Zealanders did well advanced a good deal & this morning took 900 prisoners. Things are going well all along the line & again today there has been a very heavy bombardment both from the land Batteries & the Navy. During last night the Engineers assisted the Infantry in every way possible & had 3 casualties. Some large shells 11.2" lodged along the trench where sap. Higgins & I were working today & did a good deal of damage burning a good many. The Turks are putting up a very stubborn resistance.
Entry.123:
During last night the Tommies made good progress & the Left flank & today continued doing well. In the early morning there was a terrific bombardment from the boats & Howitzers covering the Tommies advance & on other part of the Field N. Zealanders & others are doing well on the left while things are very favorable everywhere. About 9 p.m. news came through that the Tommies had taken hill 971 a very important position. Today Sap. Turnbet was practically blown to pieces by a shell while Sap. Gorham & Stallard suffered heavy shock & injuries Sec. Cpl. Bird 

was hit in the back with stray bullet, it is thought seriously. Saps Getty & Powell missing. Tommies & Australian casualties in this action said to about 5,000. Working today on barbed wire improvements.
Entry.124: The day opened with terrific bombardment from boats & land guns. All today almost without ceasing both the land guns & those of the boats have been pouring shell into the enemy’s positions. Everywhere almost from every position shells are screaming through the air at times there is a perfect roar of guns & shells. At times the Turks can be seen reaching over the back of their trenches in their hurry to get away. They are fighting very bravely though & hold their positions very firmly & in the face of terrific shell fire at times. They are inflicting very heavy losses on our boys & when we win through this engagement it will be at heavy loss. Still doing well & holding positions taken from enemy.
Entry.125:
I was working on repairs to trenches today again early this morning & last night nearly all day with only short intervals between the bursts there has been a terrific bombardment our shell appearing to be going almost everywhere the enemy is established. On Hill 971 where the Tommies had to fall back slightly last night there has been hundreds of shells falling & at times while I was in the trenches I could plainly see Turks running away from the Inferno. I was in the trenches captured from the Turk a few nights since – this afternoon. The sight there is awful, hundreds of our boys lying about dead in the open & right on the parapets & a lot even behind the trenches in some places there are heaps of them. There are a lot of Turks laying about too 

but there does not appear to be so many of them as our boys – although I was told that in the back trenches one could scarcely get along for their dead bodies. The stench is awful and altogether the sight is sickening. Our fire trench there now & theirs is about 20 yards apart & a great deal of bombing is being done. We hold the position firmly though. The enemy put in more shell the past 2 days.
Entry.126: The bombardment has been so heavy today although at intervals it has been very severe by our guns. The enemy’s guns being rather quiet. The Tommies on our left are said to be doing very well. The position elsewhere remains about the same.
Entry.127: Today has been very quiet in comparison with other days lately. Things are progressing favourably everywhere, especially on the left though slowly. There has not been much artillery fire, except at intervals when our guns would put it in f. very warm. The enemies guns have been almost silent.
Entry.128:
Today there has not been much Artillery firing from either side & things generally have been quiet. In the afternoon Sap: Higgins Cpl Mackay & I went across to be Left (Walters Ridge) to have a look & the country that the Tommies & N. Zealanders & some of our L. Horse had just advanced over. The advance has been made up a long valley between & on the slopes of "Anafarta Range" & those of "Sari Bahr" & the position is now well advanced some few miles inland & up on to the back slopes of "Battleship Hill". Some of the country over which the advance has been made is very broken being a mass of little wooded hillock & valleys very rugged & steep in appearance. Across the valley on the slope to "Anafarta" 

 

is a fairly large village but it has been much knocked about & a good deal burned by shell fire from the Fleet. There is a fairly large Mosque with a tall Tower & this appears to be intact. On our way back we had a storm at the "Beach" & while there a shrapnel shell burst quite close to us & killed one & wounded another man.
Entry.129: Things have been mostly quiet today. A few high explosive shells came across from the enemy in the afternoon but did not do much harm. Late in the afternoon we could hear a tremendous bombardment going on at Achi Baba. Things going well.
Entry.130: Things as usual today. A fair amount of Artly fire & feeble response from Enemy.
Entry.131:
Feeling very ill – off duty. Things appear to be going along as usual. 

17th

Still off duty. Feel little better today. A good deal of Artillery fire today – mostly from our guns. Royal 
George
 Edward sunk by Submarine off "Tantalous Island", on
Entry.132: with troops aboard ("British") – about 2,000, crew exclusive. Only about 600 were saved off a Hospital ship on its way to Alexandria. The "Royal Edward" was also carrying guns & Ammunition for the Peninsular.
Entry.133: Feeling better today – resumed light duties listening in tunnels. Late in afternoon the Enemy opened heavy fire with two light guns about 500 yds from our trench in front of "German Officers Trench" also with a .75 MM but did no great damage. Our Artillery fairly lively. Other things as usual.
Entry.134: Nothing of interest today. Things going well.
Entry.135: Very little Artillery fire today. Our Guns did a little but enemy very quiet. Things quiet
Entry.136:
There has been a very heavy bombardment on our left this afternoon by our Cruisers and 

land guns & it is rumoured that the Tommies & some Australians have made an advance there. Some of the Enemy’s 75. MM’s dropped into our trenches knocking things about a bit but only one man was injured. Things generally quiet & satisfactory in our Sector.
Entry.137: News through this morning (unconfirmed) that our forces on the Left yesterday afternoon & last night captured 4 lines of Enemy’s trenches & are holding them. A little bombardment by our Howitzers in our Sector. Other things quiet & satisfactory.
Entry.138: Nothing of importance today. Usual Artillery fire. Things quiet.
Entry.139: Fairly heavy fire by our Howitzers on Enemy’s position on "Johnson’s Jolly". Enemy’s Artillery quiet. Nothing fresh.
Entry.140: Nothing of importance happening out of usual. Reported Russians sunk German Sub: Dreadnought. 3 Cruisers & some Destroyers in "Baltic". Also rumour of British & French success of coast France & in North Sea. Not confirmed.
Entry.141: Nothing of much importance going today. In the afternoon the Turks fire a good many Howitzers & 75 MMs but did very little damage. Our Artillery did a little bombing. About 9 p.m. we made a demonstration with rifle fire on our left in support of something the Tommies were doing on the extreme Left. Turks answered vigorously.
Entry.142: Reported today that N. Zealanders Fifth & sixth Australian Brgds supported by Tommies made substantial advance in Left Sector last afternoon & night capturing a hill in an important position (not official). Heavy firing continued all night on left & there is still a good deal of Artillery & rifle fire going on today. Enemy Artillery devoted a good deal of attention to our trenches near Courtney’s Post doing a fair amount of damage. Early this morning enemy exploded mine near one of our Sap heads but did no damage except giving a couple of our Sappers a bad shock.
Entry.143: Things quiet today. A little enemy Artillery fire doing very little damage. Our Howitzer replying & getting well into enemy’s positions. Nothing of importance.
Entry.144: Nothing of great importance going today. Enemy quiet only subjecting us to a little Artillery. Our Howitzers fire a good many rounds into Enemy lines.
Entry.145: Late in afternoon Enemy subjected us to fairly heavy bombardment in vicinity of Courtney’s Post but did very little damage. Our Artillery replied otherwise things quiet.
Entry.146: Things quiet on both sides today, although our Howitzers did good work in afternoon dropping shells into "German Officers Trench" & on "Johnsons Jolly".
Entry.147: Enemy’s Artillery very quiet today in this Sector. Our Howitzers did good work in afternoon shelling "German Officers Trench". Things quiet generally.
Entry.148: Not much of importance today. A little shelling on both side. It is expected the enemy will make an attack between now & 6th.
Entry.149: Nothing much of importance during the day. Our Howitzers did a good deal of shelling usual & appeared to get well into the Turkish positions. 12 of our boys (Engrs) had to go into the firing line & stand to from 9 to 7 a.m. tomorrow.
Entry.150: Same as yesterday – nothing fresh. Still expecting attack from enemy. Usual shelling & some heavy stuff from enemy late in the afternoon. Warned for firing line again tonight but did not have to go.
Entry.151:
Just the usual Artillery & rifle fire today. Nothing fresh of importance.

6th 

Not much doing today out of ordinary. 5th &
Entry.152: Brigades came into lines today & were a very welcome sight to see as our boys are tired out – those who are left of them – many being ill after 20 weeks fighting. The new lads appear to be very fit & well – a good lot.
Entry.153: More of the new men came into the trenches today. The old boys are very relieved as they initiate the new comers into the art of trench warfare. Not much doing of importance.
Entry.154: Nothing of importance today out of the ordinary - a little bombardment on both sides – mostly ours.
Entry.155: Things quiet – still a little shelling as usual & the usual trench rifle fire. Nothing out of the ordinary.
Entry.156: Off duty today. Not feeling too well. Nothing fresh except arrival of new troops who are very welcome.
Entry.157: On light duty today – feeling better than yesterday. Nothing of importance. A little shelling on both side. The weather is getting much more cool. Expect to be relieved soon.
Entry.158: Resumed duty today. Not much doing of importance. A little shelling & usual rifle fire on both side.
Entry.159: Most important thing happened in our Camp today was the arrival of the 4th F Coy to relieve us. A little rain this morning. Things quiet. Do not know when being relieved.
Entry.160: Nothing fresh of interest. Same old work all along the Line.
Entry.161: Got word today that we are to leave camp tomorrow for an unknown destination for a few weeks holiday. Half Coy going, other half going later on. Think going to Lemnos Island. Things as usual along firing line.
Entry.162: Today we handed over duties to the Fourth F, Coy & we leave for only holiday tomorrow. Should have gone today but for some reason or other cannot get away.
Entry.163: Nothing for us today except getting ready to leave for our holiday. Things quiet along the firing line. Left camp about 7 p.m. & joined 2nd F Coy at "Whites Gully". Got away from Anzac Beach about 10.30 & went aboard the "Partridge". Helped unload some mail bags & then got to sleep on deck.
Entry.164:
Left from off Anzac for Lemnos about 8 a.m. & had a beautiful trip across to the Island. 

The day was beautiful & the boat ran along beautifully at about 15 knots. We made Lemnos bout 12 noon & was taken to the R.G. wharf. The Coy proceeded to camp about 2 miles away while Cpl Banks, Saps Stock, Murray H & King and myself stayed behind as baggage party.
Entry.165: We’re having a good time so far. There has been great improvement since we were here last. There are great camps & hospitals everywhere one looks, & great quantities of Military Stores, while the Harbor is full of shipping – great transports & war craft appearing to fill the Harbor. There is a remarkable difference in the appearance of the First Division Camp now and at Mena before we came away to the war. The Camp only appears to cover about the same ground as a Brigade did formerly. Today we had a look around & altogether I think we will have a good change from what we have been having on the Peninsular.
Entry.166: We’ve had a good time today – been able to have a look around & what is a great thing to us we are able to buy a good many little things we have missed for a long time – such as eggs, fruit & tinned stuff & prices are reasonable. Heard today that the strength of the original 4th Battln is now only 75. The Battlns generally appear to be terribly decimated.
Entry.167: Had a good day today. Went across to a couple of small village & made a few small purchases. The villages are all of the same of primitive kind that I have mentioned elsewhere - while the people are absolutely primitive – living the simple life absolutely.
Entry.168: Had a quiet day today. Late in the afternoon Saps Smith, Tickle & myself took a walk to a village about 4 miles away but found that it was closed so had to walk practically for nothing. All villages are now closed to troops at 6.30 p.m. & the sale of liquor is also prohibited.
Entry.169:
Had another long walk today. Saps Smith Tickle & I had a look through 3 villages. "Portiano", "Condia" & "Simandria" . All the villages like all others that we have seen on the Island are composed of square stone houses with reddish tyled roofs & blue-shuttered windows. From a distance the villages look very pretty with the coloring on the houses & green trees & bushes growing among them but when one actually gets into them the whole has a very dirty appearance & mostly the houses appear to be centuries old. "Condia" lies about 5 miles from our camp & is a fair sized village lying in a hollow on rising ground to some hills behind. Just behind the Village we climbed a very steep & rocky hill rising some hundreds of feet above the village & on top of which there is a small church. From here there is a beautiful view. Just below is the village with its square colored houses built at every conceivable angle to each other – narrow streets or lanes & trees here & there & looking down upon it from our altitude it looked very pretty indeed. Looking further afield one had in view the villages of "Simandria", "Portiano" & several others beside & all the Military camps & Hospitals & a fine view of the great Habor & all the hundreds of boats anchored there altogether the view from this hill was very beautiful

23rd

and looking further away one could plainly see the Island of 

"Imbros". We returned back to camp through Simandria feeling very tired but quite satisfied with our tour.
Entry.170: Had a quiet day in camp today. Australian mail arrived this afternoon. All having a good rest.
Entry.171: Today had a good walk to top of a high hill about 4 miles away from Camp. Sap Tickle & I scaled to the top of the mountain & while the rest of the party Saps King, Smith Murray H & Taylor & Private Gridler went on to Therma. We were able to get a splendid view from the top of this mountain which is the highest point on the Island – could see all over the Island & as the day was an ideal one the view was very fine. We descended the mountain on the western side & went to Therma which is famous for its hot springs. Here we joined the rest of our party & had a good meal & then a hot bath which was appreciated very much by us all. We all arrived back at camp after about a 10 mile walk feeling rather tired but well satisfied with our outing.
Entry.172: We did an hours Coy drill in the forenoon otherwise had a quiet day. In the afternoon Sap Tickle & I took a walk to Portiano, a village about 2 miles away & made a few purchases. Things quiet.
Entry.173: A quiet day in camp resting. Nothing doing. Heard that the Allies have had important success Western Front.
Entry.174: Coy drill forenoon. In the afternoon Cpl Lunday Sap Lloyd & I went for a walk through large Hospital camp about 1 mile away & almost to R.G. Pier about 2 miles away. Hospital Camp is a very fine camp. Reported British troops in Western camp captured. 20,000 troops – German – also large Russian success.
Entry.175: Had a med inspection today. Cannot say yet what the result will be. In the afternoon had a game of football with some of the boys. No special news to hand. All having a good spell – (rest.)
Entry.176: Nothing fresh of importance. Still having a good rest
Entry.177: Nothing doing of importance. All the troops appear to be having a good rest although they appear to be having a good deal of Drill.
Entry.178: Today Cpl Banks Saps Murray H & Gridler & Roberts took a Greek boat & sailed out to the "Floridian" (Canteen ship) for the purpose of procuring stores for the rest of the Coy. Were successful & had enjoyable time
Entry.179: No Drill or fatigues today. Late in the afternoon attended service – address by Revd McKenzie – open air – there was a fair large crowd. One of our Artillery was drowned here today. He sank owing to heart failure. We are having very warm weather. Good reports from Western Front
Entry.180: Not much doing today. Just knocking around having a fairly good time. Good news still coming through from the European Front.
Entry.181:
Today Cpls Lundy, Banks, Saps: Murray H & Gough, Tickle & I hired a Greek sailing boat & had good time visiting some of the boats in the harbor. The first boat we visited was the "Blenheim" Cruiser from there we went to the Garigan Head – a supply ship. This ship had about 20 shots fired at it from a Submarine while on her way from Alexandria to Lemnos but a French Destroyer came on the scene & chased the submarine which it is thought was sunk. We also visited the great liner "Olympic" which is crowded with English Tommies – it is said about 

8,000. All appeared to be very pleased to see us & we had a job to get away from them, got back about 8 p.m. after having a good outing.
Entry.182:
Today we played cricket against the 2nd Field Ambulance & won 119 to 56. 

7th 

Still having a good rest. Today there were several cricket matches played & some soccer matches also between some naval teams. At night the 1st Brd & the
Entry.183: Field hospital gave a concert in the Y.M.C.A. marquee & went off very well – the boys being in great good humour.
Entry.184: Nothing fresh today. Doing a little Drill and fatigues
Entry.185: This morning I went to the Dentist & had a tooth filled. Nothing much doing of interest. Having good rest.
Entry.186:
Attended Church parade this morning & again at night in the Y.M.C.A. marquee. Revd McKenzie held service & had a good attendance. 

11th

Tuesday the 1st & 2nd F. Engineers played the
Entry.187: F. Amb. cricket & lost 114 to 64. Nothing of importance except wild rumours.
Entry.188: Coy still resting & do not know when we will be going back to the Peninsular. This afternoon Sap Lloyd & I went for a walk across the country & had an enjoyable time getting some good scenery
Entry.189: Nothing going of much interest to note today. Doing a little Drill & fatigues & having a good rest. Revd Wood lectured in Y.M.C.A. subject "German Culture and how it led up to the war". Good lecture.
Entry.190: Did nothing today but a little Drill and fatigues and had a stroll across the hills in the evening
Entry.191: Things going just the same. Troops drilling & resting
Entry.192: Nothing fresh today. Had a walk around the sports ground this afternoon. There were several boats crews playing socker with Battln teams. Also there were several cricket matches in progress. The boys playing a lot of football & cricket now & it appears to be helping them to get fit.
Entry.193: This morning there was a full church Parade. We attended Service with the 2nd Brgde. At night I attended service in the Y.M.C.A. marquee. During the day thee was nothing doing of interest
Entry.194: Usual Drill & fatigues this morning. At night there was a concert in the Y.M.C.A. marquee in commemoration of the Anniversary of the day we left Australia, it being just 12 months since we left. The concert was a good success & the marquee was not nearly large enough to hold the crowds, hundreds sitting outside.
Entry.195: This afternoon Sappr Lloyd & I went across to the Hospital to see Dr McKee who has been there for about 5 week. He is getting better but is far from well. Afterwards we took a walk across the hills & had a good walk. It is rumoured tonight that the "Australians and Gurkas have taken "Hill 971" & are holding it. We all hope that the news is correct.
Entry.196: Nothing fresh today usual Drill & fatigues. A concert in the Y.M.C.A. marquee at night given by the 4th Ambulance was very good. N.Z’s & Battlns Artists took part.
Entry.197:
Usual Drill & fatigues. No fresh news. Think news about 971 not true. 

22nd

A wild bleak windy day. Play soccer today against a team from the 1st Battln & we won 2 nil. A rather amusing incident happened this morning after the rations for the day had been

drawn. Some Cross & Blackwell strawberry jam had been drawn when some of the boys thought they saw a golden opportunity & so took 4 tins apricot jam – the bane of our existence & while the Q.M. was absent exchanged them for strawberry. But there were development as S. Mjr of 2nd F Coy had witnessed the deed promptly reported the happening to our Q.M. who again reported to our O.C. when there was something doing - the whole Coy had to fall in & the tent our tent was searched & the jam duly found. However after getting a good rating from the O.C. who duly emphasised the fact on the perpertrators of the dastardly deed that if he were to push the matter they would all get 6 months hard labor, ordered the jam to be returned & the incident closed. Looked on as a huge joke by the boys! Was over to "Tommy" Ordinance this morning.
Entry.198: Today again was windy. In the afternoon a N Zealand team of Rugby players contested a game with a team of Australian players. Result easy victory for N.Z’s – about 36 to Nil. Also Military sports and drilling competition – won by
Entry.200: No church parade today. Sap. King & I went across to the Canadian Hospital to see Sap. McKee & Cpl Masters. Found Masters had left for England or elsewhere . McKee progressing slowly. Wind with some rain in the morning.
Entry.201: Our boys played Soccer against an Artillery team today & won 2 to 1. Nothing fresh going .
Entry.202: 1st Brgd leaving tomorrow morning. We expect to be leaving within a few days. Nothing else fresh doing
Entry.203: First Brgde got away this morning about 6 a.m. Had a short Route march in the forenoon full marching order. Heard that the "Marquette" has been torpedoed between here and Alexandria. Heard that about 30 Field guns went down beside about two tons ammunition – also N. Zealand 18th F. Hospital. Said about 600 saved – a number nurses drowned. Said that some Nurses were astride some of the upturned boats for 7 hours. Also rumoured that U 17 enemies Submarine was towed into Port late this afternoon. Still very windy. Played Soccer against Artillery. Neither side scored.
Entry.204: Nothing much doing today. Things as usual
Entry.205: Usual Drill & fatigues today. Have heard nothing fresh. Things going as usual. Have had very heavy weather.
Entry.206: Had to shift camp today on account of being in the Quarrantined area. The 2nd Brgde are now isolated from the rest of the camp on account of some throat trouble breaking out, Mumps or Dyptheria being the trouble.
Entry.207: Nothing of much interest today. In the morning we had the usual Church Parade. At night I attended service in the Y.M.C.A. marquee – service conducted by Mr Thompson
Entry.208: Was up before our O.C. this morning on a charge of disobeying orders. Charge laid by L. Cpl Bank. Result: Dismissed after a short lecture without a stain on my unblemished character! Usual Drill & fatigues. On sick Parade in morning.
Entry.209: A nice day. Played soccer against an Artillery team & won 3 to 2. This makes our fith match since coming here of which we have won 4 & drawn 1. Nothing else of importance
Entry.210: Nothing of importance reported today. Still resting & doing drill & fatigue in morning.
Entry.211: Was to have played soccer today against a team from the "Blenheim" but they did not turn up so we had a little practice by ourselves. Nothing fresh going.
Entry.212: Got notice about 9 p.m. that we have to be out of camp by 8 a.m. tomorrow. Going to Anzac as far as we know. No important news.
Entry.213: All bustle this morning getting away. Got away from camp about 8.30 this morning & marched about 2 miles to Turks Head Pier. Got away from there at 12 a.m. on board a barge, our next boat being The Newmarket on which we were to hand to Anzac. After lying alongside the "Harrigan" for a while we finally got away about 4 p.m. arriving off Anzac at about 9.30 p.m. It was a beautiful day one of the best since leaving on our holiday just seven weeks ago. After arriving we had to set to and unload a lot of cargo.
Entry.214: We worked all night after arriving here & it was about 5 a.m. before we finished all of us being about done up having had to work very hard all night. During the night we unloaded 4,000 cases Ball Grenades, a large quantity of 6" & 18 pounder shells, beside a good quantity of other cargo. After landing we carried our gear up into Shrapnel Gulley & Bivouaced for the day & night. We were all very tired & quite ready for a rest & sleep. Went up to where the rest of our boys were camped during the afternoon & had a look at some them. As we came ashore there were a good many stray bullets dropping in the water & a little artillery fire going on but altogether things appear to be much more quiet than formerly.
Entry.215: Shifted our position this morning to where the rest of our Coys are camped. Doing a little fatigues & getting ready to take over things when the remainder of Corp go away for their rest which I think will be tomorrow. Things appear to be going well & rather quiet. Today our guns have been putting a good many shells into the enemys lines. Sappers King, Liddicott, White, Bland, Arkinstall promoted to Lance Cpls, Lundy, Newson to Sgts. Lance Cpls Banks, Anderson, Mackinson, 2nd Cpls. Q.M.S. Wilson to Sgt Mjr (temporary) Sgt Johnstone to Q.M.S. (temporary)
Entry.216: Commenced work again today I was working on an underground shelter for Infantry to sleep in in the cold weather. The Trenches here – the 3rd Batt Lines, are in a much better state than where we were formerly near "Courtney’s Post". There does not appear to have been anything like the shells in them that were in the trenches at "Courtney’s" where they were being continuously blown in.
Entry.217: Was working today with a party on a Grenade magazine – revetting steps & placing a pipe for drainage. A good deal of shelling by our guns, land & sea.
Entry.218: Working today on placing pipe for drainage & also revetting. Finished the job. Very windy & cool. Things quiet though a good deal of shelling by our guns.
Entry.219: Working with party today placing steps in Firing line also working on underground shelter for infantry. Very windy & rather cold with a little rain. Things quiet. A little shelling.
Entry.220: Nothing of unusual importance today. Working on revetting at a new Grenade shelter. A few shells flying about as usual. Australian mail a good deal of mail appears to be missing!
Entry.221: Been working on revetting steps in Communication trench. Q.5. Our Batteries shelled enemy’s position on extreme right this afternoon. Feeble reply from Turks. Nothing else of importance
Entry.222: Very violent wind with a little rain in the late evening which made things a little uncomfortable. Very rough sea running which will greatly hamper the unloading of goods from boats. lively Artillery fire chiefly by our Batteries. Very heavy bombardment by boats on slopes Achi Baba.
Entry.223: Wind vey violent last night but quite calm today almost all trace of yesterdays boisterous weather disappeared. A fair amount of firing by our guns. Turks replying but not too energetically. Working today on timbering tunnel. Q7. Nothing of importance reported.
Entry.224: Working today timber underground cover for Infantry behind firing line. The day opened nice & fine but toward evening the wind rose rapidly & by dusk was raging a gale. A very rough sea running lashing high up on the Beach. All the boats have cleared away on account of the rough weather. Nothing out of ordinary reported. Very vivid lightning appears to be big storm coming up 7 p.m.
Entry.225: Did a little fatigue in camp today. Also had a trip to H. Qs to report for a job for tomorrow. Wind fallen considerably & sea nice & calm. Boats able to unload. Nothing of importance reported. Our guns shelled enemys positions frequently. "Beachy Bill" rather active.
Entry.226: Beautiful fine day, boats able to unload comfortably. Enemy’s guns very active shelling all along beaches. Also sent a lot of heavy Howitzers across. One shell fell into an A.M.C. Cook House just below our camp, injuring two men, I think rather badly. Been assisting in Smithy today. Fixing up new dugout tonight.
Entry.227: Had charge parties today mining two spare ammunition chambers – one in "Victoria Gully" & one in "Clarkes Valley". Fatigues from 10th Batt. Artillery put a lot of stuff into Enemys lines – also Cruiser fired a great many rounds. Enemys guns very active along Beach. A very heavy & cold wind.
Entry.228: Fatigue parties did not turn up today for ammunition chambers. Put in afternoon fixing up new dugout. The wind has been very heavy & cold during the day blowing from N.E. Shifted into new dugout this afternoon. Sap Lloyd partner. Very little Artillery fire. Enemy fairly active along Beach.
Entry.229: Had Infantry parties working on spare ammunition chambers today. About noon our Artillery opened up a very heavy bombardment also a Cruiser on some of the Turkish Gun positions. Not much reply from Enemy.
Entry.230: Had Infantry again Am. Chambers. Artillery fairly active. Enemy Artillery fairly active on Beach. Fair number casualties. Still cold windy
Entry.231: The wind has dropped today & it is much warmer than it has been lately working with Infantry parties on Am. Chambers. Artillery fire fairly brisk. Enemy sent over some large Howitzer shells but without doing much damage. A ½ doz falling into the sea. Things quiet. Nothing fresh.
Entry.232: Had Infantry parties working on chambers for spare ammunition. Today our Artillery has not fired a shot. Trying to deceive the enemy into thinking that we are evacuating the position which it is believed he already thinks. Moving some Guns into fresh positions. Also practically no rifle fire in trenches. Light wind – very cold.
Entry.233: No Artillery fire from our guns today. Enemy sent over number from Howitzer – also a good many from "Beachy Bill". Wind sprang up very suddenly during the early part last night & we also had very heavy rain – accompanied by very vivid lightning & heavy thunder. Windy today with little rain.
Entry.234: Had working parties on Am. chambers today. Wind very cold & a little rain. Things very quiet. No firing from our Artillery, not much from Enemy. Heard that French & British troops have inflicted heavy loses on Turks a not confirmed officially
Entry.235: Things quiet again today. A little firing by enemys guns – who sent over a few heavy Howitzer shells. Some time during the night snow set in accompanied by heavy wind. A few inches have fallen & it is extremely & enemy is very sloppy. It is almost impossible to get up some of the tracks it is so slippery. It has snowed a little at intervals all day, still very cold & the ground is now frozen. On our 7 day reserve ration
Entry.236: The chief feature today was a heavy bombardment of our lines – chiefly in the "Lone Pine" "Sector" by the enemy’s Artillery. The bombardment was intense & our Casualty list is heavy – not less than 150 – probably about 30 killed. Heavy Howitzers were used 8".2 – 5"12 lb shrapnel 75 & bombs. Our guns did very little in rep`ly. Had infantry party working on Bomb tunnel in "Browns Dip". Intensely cold – a little snow falling & the ground frozen hard.
Entry.237: Still very cold – the ground being frozen hard but the weather is fine & bright. Land guns doing very little on either side. A couple off Cruisers & the Battleship – Lord Nelson – did some heavy firing a little farther down the coast. Had Infantry party working on Bomb chamber. On our 7 reserve ration.
Entry.238: Nice & fine today not quite so cold as it has been lately. Today a good many shrapnel shells got into our camp & caused some casualties. Sap. Gorham & one of the 24th Batt were killed, while Sap Garden, Fowler, Masterson & another were wounded. Our Artillery did a good deal of shelling today & the enemy a fair amount.
Entry.239: Much warmer today. Artillery fairly lively – not much from enemy. Still working on bomb chamber.
Entry.240:
Usual work today. Artillery fairly busy & a good deal done by enemys guns. Very heavy bombardment by the "Nelson" & a Cruiser of a position a little down the Coast from "Gaba Tepe" 

said to be on a Gun & Head Quarters of the Turks at "Asmac Dere".
Entry.241: Our Howitzers & 18 pounders got onto some Turkish working parties in Trenches near "Gaba Tepe" today & it is thought that much damage was done as the enemy were frequently seen to be carrying away dead or wounded. Not much from enemy.
Entry.242: Our guns got onto enemys working parties again today doing it is thought a good deal of damage. Enemy sent over a good many shells. Working on bomb chamber.
Entry.243: Not much doing today by guns on either side. Working on bomb chamber. Weather still nice & warm.
Entry.244: A Cruiser & a couple of monitors got onto something today below "Gaba Tepe" – said to be artillery on the move & put in a very heavy bombardment for about half an hour. Not much from enemy’s guns. Working on bomb chamber.
Entry.245: Finish work in Vic. Gully Bomb Chamber. Enemy sent over some large shells but without doing much damage. Things fairly quiet. Warm weather. Nothing of much interest to be heard.
Entry.246: Took up duty in Tunnels in Lady Galway Road at 4 a.m. Not much shell fire from either side today things quiet.
Entry.247: Very heavy bombardment by three Cruisers & a Monitor of the Turkish Gun positions with vicinity of the "Olive Grove" inland from "Gaba Tepe". The bombardment was very intense but cannot say what the result was. Land guns very active too – not much reply from enemy. Things going as usual.
Entry.248: Things fairly quiet – not much Artillery activity on either side. This morning the 5 & 6th Batt’s got orders to proceed to a destination unknown to us at present. Also about 50 of our boys got orders to quit. We think they are to join half Coy now at Lemnos Major Dyer in Command – was our O.C. for only two days before getting orders to sail.
Entry.249: Fair amount Enemy shells – very little damage. Our guns fired a good deal of stuff into Enemy trenches & positions generally. A number of 4th Field Coy left today. Things going well. About 30 Infantry drafted into our Coy today. Only about 12 of our old boys left – about same of re-Inforcements.
Entry.250:
More troops going away tonight – appears to be troops leaving each night. A lot of work being done preparing winter quarters underground for troops. Large quantities of stores being destroyed 

14th

Great activity – large quantities of stores being destroyed. Everything points to total evacuation of Anzac. Number Artillery men 2nd 4 Coy & part of
Entry.251: F Coy. A.M.C. etc left tonight. Had a few parting shots from "Beachy Bill" but no casualties.
Entry.252:
Arrived at Lemnos Island today. Very heavy wind & sea rather rough

Had a little rain on the trip over. Pitched tents late in afternoon all feeling very tired. Very large number war craft in Harbor – also many large transports – travelled over in "Snaefel"
Entry.253: Did very little today – just resting and making ourselves comfortable. Large number troops arrived from Anzac & there is no doubt that there is to be a general evacuation of the position. Rumoured we are to go to Egypt.
Entry.254: Things quiet. A good many troops coming in from Anzac. Did a little Drill this morning & a little fatigue. Beautiful weather.
Entry.255: Took up our quarters with the rest of the Coy today. Sections reallotted. 2nd Cpl Banks & I are the only two of the old boys to remain in No 1 Sec. Troops still coming in from Anzac. So far the movement of evacuation has been entirely successful.
Entry.256: Working on fatigue this morning building insinerator. Troops still coming in from Anzac. Movement still successful. Cloudy & cool.
Entry.257: As far as we can gather the Troops are about all off Anzac. The movement was completely successful there being practically no casualties. The movement has been wonderfully successful. Drilling this morning, nothing fresh.
Entry.258: Things going quietly. Very heavy rain this morning. Cpt. Biden of "Duntroon" & one of our late Coy Sec. officers died in hospital this morning at about 2 a.m. We attended funeral in the afternoon
Entry.259: Things going as usual – nothing of importance. Coy doing a little Drill & fatigues. Weather overcast & cloudy & cool. Was out on the harbour this afternoon & visited "Carrigan Head" & other boats for purpose of obtaining stores
Entry.260: Got orders early this morning to pack up & be ready to go aboard by 12 noon. Was taken to the "Caledonia" in the "Alls Well" a mine layer & got aboard about 2 p.m. "Caledonia" is a fine boat of the "Anchor" line. We have good sleeping berths. Do not know where we are going – but think to Alexandria. Expect to leave tomorrow morning. Weather squally.
Entry.261: Left "Mudros Harbour" about 10 a.m. Apparently steering at straight course for Alexandria & running about 15 knots per hour. Weather squally & sea rather choppy with a fair swell. Got through day safely although enemy precaution is being taken against submarine attack as there are supposed to be about 30 enemy submarines in these & Mediterranean waters. All hands are wearing life belts night & day.
Entry.262: A nice fine day – had Xmas on the water. Nothing of importance happened – have escaped from enemy’s submarine craft so far.
Entry.263: When we got out of bed this morning Alexandria was within sight & we anchored in the stream at about 8 a.m. Laid in Harbor all day. Beautiful fine day. Had good passage across. Expect to leave for Cairo in the morning early.
Entry.264:
Left Alexandria today at about 10 p.m. 1st 2nd & 3rd Coys all travelled 

together. We expected to go somewhere near Cairo but lobbed at Tel-El- Kebir the scene of the great battle in – I think 82.
Entry.265:
Landed here at Tel-El-Kebir at about 5.30 a.m. feeling as usual rather tired. The country here is the usual level Egyptian Sunday wastes that we have been used to. There is a large canal close to our camp & a lot of cultivation along the banks. It is about 60 miles from Cairo to this place & 8 to Zag-a-Zig & Ishalia. 
We are on Guard today. The weather is much
 warmer here than at the Peninsular. Troops are arriving in large numbers night & day. It is thought that there will be trouble here before long.
Entry.266: On Guard today. Nothing of importance going except that troops are still arriving night & day.
Entry.267: Usual Camp work & drilling going today. Came off Guard at 9 a.m. & had leave in the afternoon & had an hour at a small native village close by – myself & Saps. Moane & Keig. Usual dirty native village. There is beautiful level land along the canal – much green stuff growing & large orange & mandarine groves.
Entry.268: Got leave for Cairo today & left about 4.40 p.m. Had a good trip & arrived at Cairo about the "Kediveal Hotel". The railway line from Tel-El-Kebir to Zag-a-Zig & from there on to Cairo passes through beautiful cultivated land.
